abstract: Editorial argues that the Justice Department is right to contest a judge's decision to strike down a century-old ban on direct corporate contributions to political candidates for federal office; argues that if individuals can easily get around their contribution limits by funneling money through corporate entities crucial campaign finance laws would be rendered meaningless.
snippet: A judge’s ruling that struck down the century-old ban on direct corporate contributions to political candidates for federal office is worth fighting.
